column1: Business
Asia-Pacific shares have advanced today
column2: putting world equities on course to extend their bull run for a 12th consecutive session as optimism about the global economic recovery and expectations of low interest rates drive investments into riskier assets. Severe freezing weather in the US has helped push oil prices to a 13-month high. The MSCI index of Asia-Pacific shares ticked up 0.45% while Japan’s Nikkei rose 0.4% to a 30-year high. The Hang Seng surged 1.79% to a 32-month high in its first session since Thursday following the lunar new year holidays. Mainland Chinese markets will remain closed until this Thursday while Wall Street was also shut on Monday. The FTSE has picked up on the positive vibe and is set to open higher. The pound is worth $1.394 and €1.148 at time of writing.

column1: The papers

A quarantined arrival giving the thumbs-down from behind a hotel window features across several front pages today. Others look out longingly – the Metro calls it the “Radisson blues”. The i has “Border farce on day one of new hotel quarantine” –picking up
column2: as our story does on how border staff
column3: received their instructions – a lengthy email with five attachments – only two and a half hours before they came into force. The Guardian has “Anger over Cummings role in Covid contract” and stars calling for the government to bring back visa-free work in the EU for creative practitioners.

column1: View image in fullscreen Guardian front page
column2: Tuesday 16 February 2021.

column1: “Johnson: this must be the final lockdown”. That’s the Telegraph while the Times has “Vaccination is reducing admissions and deaths” – which might further embolden Tory MPs who believe high vaccination rates are enough to warrant lifting restrictions. The Express says “PM: we can be optimistic … but no time to relax”.

The Sussexes’ decision to go even more public via an Oprah Winfrey interview is everywhere. “Harry and Meghan: the final straw” says the Mail: it reports they are set to be stripped of their remaining royal patronages. The Mirror can’t resist doing it as “Royal soap Oprah” and says the palace “fears explosive claims”. The FT leads with “JLR ditches diesel in plan to go electric in 15 years” – our version of that news here. Its picture lead is Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
column2: who has become the first female and first African leader of the World Trade Organization.

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/feb/09/portrait-of-a-killer-art-class-in-one-of-mexicos-most-notorious-prisons;Portrait of a killer: art class in one of Mexico’s most notorious prisons;"After two decades working in some of Mexico’s toughest prisons
column2: warden Ángeles Zavala thought she had seen it all. Then one morning in 2016
column3: she arrived for work at Puente Grande prison to find a local artist waiting for her. The man had recently completed a few workshops with inmates in another part of the prison
column4: and had a proposal. Speaking in rapid-fire bursts
column5: the artist told Ángeles he wanted to move into the maximum-security prison and live there for six weeks
column6: in order to teach some of the country’s most dangerous inmates how to paint. Through art therapy
column7: he would help them change their lives. And he wanted to start with the veteran narcos of Mexico’s violent drug war.

column1: “I was thinking: ‘What is wrong with him?’” Ángeles said later. “‘Everyone is trying to get out and César wants to live here?’”
César Aréchiga
column2: then 36
column3: had achieved a mild degree of regional renown for his realist paintings the size of barn doors. He was a bear of a man
column4: but with his artistic verve
column5: clear-framed glasses and pack-a-day smoking habit
column6: he seemed more at home in Guadalajara’s trendy coffee shops than in a prison full of gang members. Ángeles was intrigued. There are almost no art programmes for Mexican prisoners; few people are brave enough to teach inside the prisons. If César was crazy enough to try
column7: why not see what might happen?

column1: Ángeles started drawing up a list of inmates
column2: and chose 15 who were either clinically depressed or had a record of fighting. If César was looking for a challenge
column3: she reasoned
column4: she would send him those who seemed most in need of change. “To be honest
column5: my first thought was: ‘All his art supplies will be stolen
column6: and that will be it.’”

column1: César grew up in Guadalajara
column2: Mexico’s third-biggest metropolitan area and a narco stronghold. His life had been marked by the violence plaguing the country as rival cartels vied for control of the lucrative drug trafficking routes into the US. In 1993
column3: when César was a boy
column4: he and his family were caught in a shootout at Guadalajara’s airport. They hid behind a ticket counter
column5: the sound of gunfire and screaming reverberating around the terminal for what felt like hours.

column1: View image in fullscreen César Aréchiga. Photograph: Carlos Cruz
“More than anything
column2: I remember the panic on people’s faces
column3: ” César said. A Mexican cardinal was killed in the shootout
column4: which was subsequently seen as a harbinger of the violence that would come to consume much of the country. Later
column5: as a young man
column6: César was on his way to school when gunfire erupted on the street around him. A few feet away
column7: a man crumpled to the ground as the shooter sped past on a motorcycle.

column1: Mexico’s murder rate has more than tripled since 2007
column2: shortly after the military began an offensive against the cartels that have supplied the US’s insatiable demand for cocaine
column3: heroin and cannabis. More than 350
column4: 000 people have been killed and 72
column5: 000 disappeared in the years since. César painted wounded flesh and the outlines of missing people
column6: incorporating statistics on crimes and fragments of police reports on his work. His first exhibited work
column7: titled Numberless Victim
column8: depicts a young person
column9: bound and gagged
column10: but looking defiantly at the viewer. It was this work that introduced him to Puente Grande prison: he won a contract to paint a large outdoor mural there in 2016. It was a difficult process. As he tried to work
column11: prisoners crowded around him. One inmate asked him how much he was getting paid for the gig
column12: a hint of menace in his voice. Another prisoner said if he really wanted to help
column13: the artist should teach them to make handicrafts to sell instead. Under the blazing sun in the open air courtyard
column14: the idea grew on him: why not teach inmates to paint and sculpt?

column1: “Killers
column2: that was my idea
column3: ” he said. It would be therapeutic. He would give people who had used their hands to destroy an opportunity to create.

column1: It was
column2: in many respects
column3: a ridiculous idea. César wanted to enter the prison with scissors
column4: knives and sculpting gouges. But he had an uncanny knack for convincing people
column5: and eventually got permission from the authorities.

column1: Patricia Ortiz
César assembled a small crew to help with his project and film the result – because
column2: he figured
column3: no one would believe him otherwise. None of them had worked in a prison before. One of the first people he turned to was Patricia Ortiz
column4: an actor and old friend. Patricia has elfin features
column5: a pale complexion and long brown hair. She has a tendency to speak in stories
column6: her expressive face coming alive as she recounts a previous job working on a theatre project in Tepito
column7: the historic home of gang activity in Mexico City.

column1: When César told her about his art therapy project
column2: she jumped at the chance to be involved. They are the same age
column3: but Patricia speaks of César with a loving frustration usually reserved for wayward younger siblings. From her perspective
column4: her role was to keep him in line. She knew his impulsive nature and stubbornness had got this project off the ground
column5: but she feared it could also get them into trouble. “César lives a life of extremes
column6: ” she told me. “When you’re beside him you can experience incredible things
column7: but also some of the worst things in your life.”

column1: On an autumn morning in 2016
column2: Claudia Becerril was at her therapist’s office in Mexico City talking about the six weeks she was about to spend working in prison. Small but tough
column3: with a broad smile
column4: she was the only woman on her university cinematography course. One tutor tried to haze her into quitting by giving her the heaviest equipment to carry. A keen rock climber
column5: Claudia managed just fine. Her doubts about working in prison were less about the inmates than herself. Fresh out of a long-term relationship
column6: she was feeling a little fragile. Was a maximum security prison the best place to get over a breakup?

column1: A few months earlier
column2: César had come across Claudia’s reel from film school and noticed how she had expertly filmed sculpture using close shots of hands at work. He decided she was a perfect fit for the project
column3: and asked if she wanted to join him at Puente Grande. She said yes immediately. She believed in rehabilitation
column4: and jumped at the chance to understand what drove the violence that was scarring the country. Like César and Patricia
column5: she was part of a generation of middle-class Mexicans who grew up in the shadow of the drug war. What better way to understand the seemingly senseless violence than to go to prison?

column1: View image in fullscreen Cinematographer Claudia Becerril
On the first day of the project
column2: César
column3: Patricia and Claudia were still a few miles from the prison when they started losing phone signal. (The prison’s signal blockers are supposed to make it impossible to reach the outside world.) As they rounded a bend
column4: Puente Grande’s hulking grey outline came into view. In the car park
column5: throngs of vendors hawked goods as family members queued at the gate to bring food to loved ones inside. With more than 10
column6: 000 inmates and a constant flow of visitors and staff
column7: the Puente Grande complex felt more like a city than a prison.

column1: Puente Grande is
column2: for many
column3: a symbol of successive governments’ failure to control organised crime as well as crime’s power to corrupt authorities. Joaquín “El Chapo” Guzmán escaped from the prison in 2001
column4: purportedly in a laundry cart. (According to another version of the tale
column5: the guards simply opened the doors and he walked straight out.) In 2016
column6: Mexico was approaching the 10th anniversary of the disastrous “war on drugs”
column7: and the country’s murder rate was surging toward an all-time high. Whatever the authorities were doing
column8: it wasn’t working.

column1: Entering the prison was like going into a labyrinth. Accompanied by two security guards
column2: the three artists walked down concrete passageways as clanging doors reverberated loudly in the enclosed space. When César entered the communal area
column3: he could glimpse daylight from windows at the top of high walls. He waited in an empty room as guards led in the inmates
column4: shackled at the wrists and ankles. Lined up in silence
column5: the inmates listened as César made his pitch. He would move his apartment into the prison
column6: he said: “I’ll be in your house
column7: and you’ll be in mine.”

column1: The inmates just stared.
One Honduran American inmate
column2: Parvis – then in his early 30s with a boyish face
column3: short hair and tattoos creeping up his neck – had spent the best part of a decade in prisons in the US and in Mexico. He recalled the curious sight of seeing an educated
column4: well-spoken man who appeared to have wandered into their world by mistake. “He was very sincere
column5: ” Parvis said of that first meeting
column6: “but you could tell he was afraid. He was shitting bricks.”

column1: The prisoners had doubts. Art classes
column2: cameras
column3: women in the prison? It was all hard to believe. More importantly
column4: they were concerned that by appearing on film
column5: they risked revealing to their enemies where they could be found. “I didn’t know if as soon as I got back out I’m going to die
column6: if they’re going to pick me up
column7: chop me up and kill me
column8: ” said Parvis. They also didn’t know anything about César and his crew – who were these people
column9: and who had sent them? To assuage those concerns
column10: César promised that once the course was complete
column11: he would return to the prison and show them the footage before he showed it to anyone else. If the prisoners didn’t like some parts
column12: he would delete them. They had power of veto.

column1: View image in fullscreen Parvis
column2: one of the prisoners taking part in César Aréchiga’s art project inside Puente Grande prison in Mexico. Photograph: Claudia Becerril/45 Days in Harvar

column1: Despite their misgivings
column2: the inmates agreed
column3: eager to do anything that got them out of their underground cells. Taking part in the workshop could also help their cases before the Parole Board. César and his crew began moving his furniture and art equipment into the prison. He brought sofas
column4: armchairs
column5: coffee tables
column6: rugs
column7: plants and a chess set from his home. Then came the turpentine
column8: paintbrushes
column9: easels
column10: two tonnes of dried clay
column11: staplers
column12: sculpting tools and scissors for workshops. The guards scanned and inspected each item for hidden weapons or drugs.

column1: The first day of class was on 1 November 2016. Hands manacled behind their backs
column2: the men were led single-file out of their underground cells and up to the hall. The doors opened and the prisoners stared at the furniture bathed in sunlight. As the guards uncuffed the men
column3: César stood waiting to shake their hands
column4: as though he was welcoming them into his home.

column1: One prisoner plopped down in César’s chair and exclaimed to no one in particular: “It’s been 15 years since I’ve sat in an armchair.” Another stretched out on a sofa and promptly fell asleep.
César tried to sound upbeat
column2: and began showing the men all the material they would be using: canvas
column3: clay
column4: paper. It was hard to tell whether they were interested in the work
column5: but the men revelled in their status as the privileged few allowed to spend hours out of their cells. Behind them
column6: inmates not in the workshop pressed their faces up to the glass to watch. As César gave instructions
column7: he was interrupted by shouting outside. Turning
column8: he saw a gigantic figure banging on the glass and demanding to be let in.

column1: The next day
column2: the giant returned and again asked to take part. César asked the warden about him. “He has the worst disciplinary record in the prison
column3: ” Ángeles told him. “He won’t be able to do the workshop.” But César insisted
column4: impressed by the man’s enthusiasm
column5: and eventually Ángeles relented. Better known as “Escalera” or “the Ladder” for his towering 6ft 6in frame
column6: Enrique was charismatic
column7: funny and had the square jaw and strong features of a Hollywood leading man. But he could also be unpredictable
column8: aggressive and deceptive.

column1: César thought clay would be a good place to start. As he poured dry clay and water on to a large tarp in the middle of the room
column2: he told the prisoners to take off their shoes and use their feet to mix the materials. “We’re not allowed to take our shoes off
column3: it’s against the rules
column4: ” one prisoner replied as guards watched from a distance. César waved away their objections. “Just do it
column5: ” he told them. A few minutes later
column6: he watched as two members of rival cartels gleefully stomped up and down shoeless in the dirt alongside each other
column7: orange uniforms rolled up to their knees.

column1: “We were like little kids running around
column2: ” Parvis said. “Outside
column3: we were enemies. We would probably have killed each other as soon as we saw each other
column4: but here we were having fun in the mud.”

column1: When it was time to make sculptures with the fresh clay
column2: a diminutive man with salt-and-pepper hair and a wide
column3: infectious grin quickly demonstrated his passion for the task. He would ignore the surrounding chatter and become absorbed in the work. “I’ve spent a long time looking at my hands and how they have changed over the years
column4: ” he said while holding them up
column5: his face alight with the pleasure of recognising this newfound talent. Claudia
column6: the photographer
column7: said: “Only later did we learn he used to make bombs.”

column1: View image in fullscreen César and one of his students painting inside Puente Grande. Photograph: Claudia Becerril/45 Days in Harvar
Claudia had been warned to avoid divulging personal details in case it made her an extortion target. But as she sat around the dining table where the crew and the prisoners shared meals
column2: she was honest when answering the prisoners’ questions. When they asked what she earned in a month
column3: she hesitated a second before telling them. The inmates just laughed. “I used to tip that much in the bar!” Enrique said
column4: howling with laughter.

column1: Parvis – despite being in his 30s and having eyeballs tattooed on his eyelids
column2: and what looks like an anchor on his right cheek – had a youthful enthusiasm and openness that made him seem more like a teenage rapper than a prison veteran. When César had the inmates cover the prison’s brick walls with huge sheets of brown paper and paint over them
column3: Parvis began drawing the anarchist circle-A
column4: a large version of the tattoo he got on his hand as a rebellious teenager. Then he added multicoloured handprints and hearts.

column1: One prisoner
column2: a small man with a downturned mouth and penetrating gaze
column3: recalled his life before prison while César painted his portrait. As a young man he had planned to follow in the footsteps of his upright
column4: hardworking father who had waited tables and washed dishes until he eventually ran a restaurant. “I saw how people looked down on him for being a worker
column5: ” he said. “At that point I get this rage inside me
column6: this bitterness.” He realised that whatever his father achieved
column7: people wouldn’t respect him. “Then I got tired of serving. And I wanted other people to serve me
column8: ” he said. “That’s why I did certain things.”

column1: Enrique
column2: the towering troublemaker
column3: turned out to be César’s star pupil. The two shared a dry
column4: sometimes dark sense of humour. Through Enrique’s jokes about corrupt politicians and bribing judges
column5: César felt like he’d glimpsed the truth about how Mexico really worked. And in return
column6: Enrique threw himself into the work
column7: quickly demonstrating an eye for painting. For the first few weeks
column8: the inmates kept up their tough-guy facades when talking about the past. Enrique was the first to open up.

column1: That moment came in the third week. During a break between classes
column2: Enrique sat on the floor
column3: sketching an outline of his cell for César. There was a brief silence as the conversation dwindled. “I have kind of a dramatic story
column4: ” Enrique said
column5: long arms hugging his knees.

column1: “What’s that?” César asked.
“I’m only here because of some stupid shit
column2: ” Enrique replied. He explained that he had attended one of Mexico’s best universities in Tijuana
column3: and had been studying to become a dentist. One day in his second year of college
column4: Enrique heard from a friend that another student had grabbed his girlfriend’s butt. Enrique punched the guy so hard the man stumbled backward
column5: fell from a second-storey balcony and died. As a result
column6: Enrique served a year in a notorious maximum-security prison near Tijuana. “And that’s when I got connected
column7: ” he said. “The truth is
column8: this is Harvard
column9: this is the university of crime.”

column1: View image in fullscreen Enrique
column2: another of the prisoners taking part. Photograph: Claudia Becerril/45 Days in Harvar

column1: For César
column2: the conversation was a revelation. In Enrique’s story he saw the tragedy of the criminal justice system. But it was also personal. In Enrique’s version of events
column3: where one mistake threw his life off course
column4: César saw himself.

column1: Years earlier
column2: César had seemed bound for a promising career in the US. But while returning from a visit back to Mexico
column3: he was questioned by US customs officials over apparent irregularities in the sale of several of his works in New York
column4: where he’d been living for five years
column5: rubbing shoulders with the art scene’s elite. Adamant it was a mistake
column6: he says he tried to explain away the issue
column7: grew frustrated when he couldn’t
column8: and raised his voice. Next thing he knew
column9: he was in Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention awaiting deportation. That was the moment everything went wrong. His assets frozen and art contacts suddenly worthless
column10: in a matter of days César Aréchiga went from being a fast-rising artist in New York to being broke
column11: banned from the US and forced to move back in with his parents.

column1: Ultimately
column2: he got back on his feet
column3: though not back to New York. César was middle-class and knew how to speak to the rich and powerful
column4: but he knew that one mistake could change everything. “I saw those guys in orange
column5: ” César said
column6: “and I felt that fear
column7: that
column8: for some stupid shit
column9: I wouldn’t get out of there.”

column1: Enrique deputised himself as César’s right-hand man. When the others remained stretched out on the sofas after lunch
column2: Enrique would stand up and say: “Let’s get to work.” And they did. No one else would get away with this
column3: but from Enrique they tolerated it.

column1: When a gouge for sculpting clay went missing one afternoon
column2: Patricia started to worry. It could be used as a shiv
column3: and they had to find it – the project depended on it. At the same time
column4: if they accused the inmates of stealing and the gouge was merely mislaid
column5: the crew could ruin the delicate trust they’d built. Then Enrique stepped in. “No one leaves here until we find it
column6: ” he announced. They all searched the room
column7: and the gouge reappeared.

column1: Patricia’s role was to build trust with the inmates. She made a point of showing that she wasn’t scared of them by making eye contact and engaging them in small talk about their soccer teams or home towns. When it was time to start a new project
column2: she would guide them with a gentle hand on the shoulder. As the prisoners painted
column3: she would circle the room and ask about their work
column4: which often led to other topics.

column1: View image in fullscreen A prisoner sculpting with clay. Photograph: Claudia Becerril/45 Days in Harvar
Santiago
column2: a middle-aged man with a fatherly air
column3: was initially reserved
column4: but began opening up as he painted a scene from his home town. “You listen. You talk to us like normal people
column5: ” he said
column6: by way of explanation. Parvis
column7: in particular
column8: spoke for hours while he worked on landscapes. “You can’t talk to another cartel member and tell them ‘I feel bad about what I did’
column9: ” Parvis said. “You don’t do that. You just don’t do that.” With a 36-year sentence hanging over him
column10: he wasn’t sure he would ever get out. But the interest César and his team showed encouraged Parvis to keep thinking about what had led him to this point.

column1: Over long afternoons painting and talking with Patricia
column2: Parvis could almost forget where he was. He told her about the tough years he spent in Honduras as a small child amid worsening gang violence; how the family was forced to flee when his father was threatened
column3: making the perilous journey through Mexico and into the US. They settled in Arizona
column4: but when his father was arrested
column5: Parvis was placed in a group home. He joined a gang soon after.

column1: As Patricia listened
column2: she thought how easy it would be for anyone who had grown up like that to make the same mistake. But then a thought occurred to her: “I love this bastard
column3: but I knew these eyes that I was staring into were the last thing someone saw before he killed them.”

column1: Enrique mellowed as the weeks wore on. Talking about his estranged family seemed to help him find a new
column2: more sensitive side of himself. When he arrived one day looking morose
column3: he said simply: “I miss my kids.” The structure of the classes also helped him find purpose. “Normally people like us don’t like to work
column4: ” Enrique said. “But this teaches me to keep going. I look at myself and I like what I see.”

column1: When guards handed Enrique a stack of letters from his family
column2: going back months
column3: he flew into a rage
column4: convinced they had been intentionally withheld as punishment for fighting. But César managed to calm him down. By the end of the day
column5: Enrique and César were laughing
column6: smoking cigarettes and reading the letters together.

column1: With their newfound liberty in the classes
column2: the prisoners also began to reexamine the hardships of prison life they had become accustomed to – and the contrast could be brutal. After a day painting landscapes or talking about his childhood
column3: Parvis began to resent the pat-downs
column4: daily searches of his cell and having a camera watch him every moment of every day. For the inmates in César’s programme
column5: each search threatened to cut short the time they could spend in the workshop. “When the guards start getting a little strict with you
column6: you’re like: ‘You know what
column7: I could end up killing for this moment
column8: dude
column9: because I’m probably never going to get it again
column10: ’” he said.

column1: The growing bond between crew and inmates caused other problems
column2: too. With the attention and special treatment they lavished on the workshop’s chosen few
column3: the crew had inadvertently destabilised the prison’s balance of power.

column1: Things escalated one lunchtime. The crew and inmates were lined up to eat together
column2: as usual. One by one
column3: they were handed trays of food by the guards. But when Patricia arrived
column4: they told her there was none left. Something had gone wrong with the order
column5: they said. The inmates were used to this: Santiago
column6: the normally reserved older prisoner
column7: offered to go without so Patricia could eat. She snapped. “We want food for everyone
column8: ” she yelled
column9: now surrounded by other prisoners.

column1: View image in fullscreen César (in black) and his students. Photograph: Claudia Becerril/45 Days in Harvar
“We’ve had enough
column2: you bastards
column3: ” a prisoner yelled. A chair went flying. Patricia saw Santiago
column4: surrounded by other prisoners
column5: his face filled with rage.

column1: Fearing a riot
column2: César pulled Patricia aside. “What are you doing?” he hissed. She caught herself and backed down. Patricia asked Santiago to help her
column3: while César herded the inmates back to the workshop to avoid further confrontation.

column1: “It was stupid
column2: ” Patricia said. “I was able to walk out the door and eat in a hotel
column3: and they would end up in the hole.”

column1: After several weeks
column2: Enrique was so trusted that no one questioned him putting himself in charge of helping to collect supplies at the end of the day. Then one evening after packing up
column3: a crew member told César some paints were missing. He suspected Enrique was stealing them to trade for cigarettes. César was initially disappointed
column4: but decided not to immediately confront Enrique. First of all
column5: he didn’t want to alienate a man who had become the poster boy of his art therapy workshops. But he later chose to believe that the theft signalled something else: others in the prison wanted to paint enough that they were willing to trade cigarettes for art supplies.

column1: At times
column2: this growing closeness made the crew uncomfortable. While chatting in a group
column3: one inmate made an offhand comment about another
column4: a younger man who kept to himself. “He’s the one who killed those students
column5: ” the first prisoner said. When she left the prison later
column6: Patricia couldn’t stop thinking about it. She felt the dissonance of going from protesting against the 2014 disappearance (and presumed killing) of 43 students
column7: an event that shocked the world
column8: to teaching art to someone who had apparently committed similar crimes against other student demonstrators. She thought of the thousands of people looking for their disappeared relatives in mass graves
column9: then saw herself teaching those responsible how to paint: “I started to ask myself whether we really were doing something to benefit people
column10: or if we were led by our egos or a romanticisation of art.”

column1: At the end of the course they ate a last meal together
column2: and said their goodbyes
column3: hugging like old friends.

column1: About a year later
column2: César was painting in his studio in downtown Guadalajara. Outside
column3: trucks carrying rifle-wielding police in body armour trundled through the oppressive traffic. His phone bleeped – it was Enrique. He was using a Facebook profile under a different name
column4: but César recognised his photo. “What’s up fatso
column5: ” wrote Enrique
column6: who
column7: despite his affection for César
column8: was never exactly polite. Enrique was out
column9: he explained
column10: and back living with his wife and children
column11: fixing up motorbikes. “I’m trying to make this work
column12: ” he said. He sounded happy.

column1: On the walls of César’s apartment hung portraits of the inmates he had painted. There was Enrique
column2: looking dashing
column3: and Parvis. Santiago’s clay sculptures
column4: of birds and people in Aztec and Olmec styles
column5: stood on a table in his living room. Cesar felt hopeful that his project had made a positive impact
column6: at least for someone.

column1: A few weeks later

WHAT DOES THE 25TH AMENDMENT SAY? CAN TRUMP'S CABINET REALLY TOPPLE HIM? The 25th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution deals with presidential authority in the event of death or removal from office
column2: and was ratified in 1967
column3: in the wake of John F Kennedy's assassination. What does the 25th Amendment say? It is in four sections
column4: all dealing with the president leaving office during his or her elected term. The first section states that the vice president takes over the Oval Office if the president dies or resigns – or is removed – something which the original Constitution did not clearly state. Presidents of course can be removed by impeachment
column5: a feature of the constitution from the start. They can also be removed through the 25th Amendment - of which more below. Section II states that if the vice president dies
column6: or resigns – or is fired – both the House and Senate have to confirm a new vice president. Until 1967
column7: presidents could change vice presidents mid-term on their own if they got the vice president to agree to resign - not something that actually happened
column8: but which was possible in principle. Section III makes clear that a president can temporarily delegate his powers to the vice president
column9: and later reclaim them when he - or she - is capable of serving. This is most often invoked if a president is under the influence of surgical anesthetic for a short period of time. Section IV is the amendment's most controversial part: it describes how the president can be removed from office if he is incapacitated and does not leave on his own. The vice president and 'a majority of either the principal officers of the executive departments or of such other body as Congress may by law provide' must write to both the president pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House
column10: saying that 'the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office.' The term principal officers of the executive departments would normally mean the cabinet secretaries. So at least eight of the president's 15 most senior Cabinet members together with the vice president must agree that a president should be removed before any plan can move forward. Notifying the House Speaker and the Senate president pro tempore is the act that immediately elevates the vice president to an 'acting president' role. The deposed president can contest the claim
column11: giving the leaders of the bloodless coup four days to re-assert their claims to the House and Senate. Congress then has two days to convene – unless it is already in session – and another 21 days to vote on whether the president is incapable of serving. A two-thirds majority in both houses is required to make that determination. As soon as there is a vote with a two-thirds majority
column12: the president loses his powers and is removed
column13: and the vice president stops acting and is sworn in as president. But if 21 days of debate and votes ends without a two-thirds majority
column14: the president gets back his powers. What could happen to trigger the 25th Amendment? Vice President Mike Pence and eight of the 15 'principal' Cabinet members would have to agree to notify Congress that President Donald Trump was incapable of running the country. That group is made up of the Secretary of State
column26: Veterans Affairs Secretary and Homeland Security Secretary. Their formal notification would go to the House Speaker and
column29: the Senate's most senior member. As soon as the letter is sent

column32: or a joint committee. Pence would still have to agree with its conclusion and then write formally to the Speaker and president pro tempore. Or another possibility is that the pool of 'principal officers' is considered to be bigger than the 15 and a majority of that group call Trump incapable. What if Trump does not agree? The 25th Amendment allows Congress to appoint its own panel to evaluate the president instead of relying on the Cabinet – the men and women who work most closely with Trump – to decide on a course of action. No. The vice president can resign or be impeached and removed - but he does not serve at the pleasure of the president. Is there any precedent for this? No. Only Section III
